articles.headline: To Save Fuel, Airlines Find No Speck Too Small
articles.snippet: Airlines are scrutinizing every step of their operations, searching for new ways to cut fuel bills.
articles.abstract: Airlines are scrutinizing every step of their operations, searching for new ways to cut fuel bills.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s airlines are scrutinizing every step of their operations, from the tarmac to the sky, and from the nose to the tail of their planes, searching for new ways to cut their soaring fuel bills.

articles.headline: Standing Up for Workers’ Rights in Japan
articles.snippet: Japan’s salarymen have borne the brunt of its economic decline, enduring lower wages, job insecurity and long hours of unpaid overtime. Now, a few are fighting back.
articles.abstract: Japan’s salarymen have borne the brunt of its economic decline, enduring lower wages, job insecurity and long hours of unpaid overtime. Now, a few are fighting back.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Japan’s salarymen, famous for their work ethic and their corporate loyalty, fueled this nation’s industrial rise. But more recently, they have borne the brunt of its economic decline, enduring lower wages, job insecurity and long hours of unpaid overtime.

articles.headline: Korean Leader Considers Ways to Rework Government
articles.snippet: Speaking to businessmen at his office, President Lee Myung-bak gave his first comment on the massive outdoor rally against his four-month-old leadership.
articles.abstract: Speaking to businessmen at his office, President Lee Myung-bak gave his first comment on the massive outdoor rally against his four-month-old leadership.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL — President Lee Myung-bak pledged a "new beginning" on Wednesday as he contemplated reorganizing his unpopular government which has been shaken by the biggest anti-government demonstrations in two decades.

articles.headline: Paulson’s Path to China: Progress, but Miles to Go
articles.snippet: Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson said that the U.S.-China relationship is “growing in a positive direction,” but that he would press for a more open Chinese economy.
articles.abstract: Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson said that the U.S.-China relationship is “growing in a positive direction,” but that he would press for a more open Chinese economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Two years ago, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. left Goldman Sachs and joined the Bush administration, hoping to use his expertise and contacts to ease economic tensions with China. His other goal was to stop Congress from passing legislation that might make tensions worse.

articles.headline: Fund Figure Disappears on Date Set for Prison
articles.snippet: A little more than an hour before a former hedge fund manager was to report to prison, his car was found abandoned on a bridge over the Hudson River with “Suicide Is Painless” etched on its hood.
articles.abstract: A little more than an hour before a former hedge fund manager was to report to prison, his car was found abandoned on a bridge over the Hudson River with “Suicide Is Painless” etched on its hood.
articles.lead_paragraph: A little more than an hour before a former hedge fund manager was to report to federal prison on Monday, his sport utility vehicle was found abandoned on a bridge over the Hudson River with the phrase “Suicide Is Painless” written in dust on its hood.

articles.headline: In Europe, Debate Over Islam and Virginity
articles.snippet: Many young Muslim women are caught between Europe’s freedoms and the traditions of their parents’ generations.
articles.abstract: Many young Muslim women are caught between Europe’s freedoms and the traditions of their parents’ generations.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  The operation in the private clinic off the Champs-Élysées involved one semicircular cut, 10 dissolving stitches and a discounted fee of $2,900.
articles.byline: By Elaine Sciolino and Souad Mekhennet

articles.headline: Beloved Characters as Reimagined for the 21st Century
articles.snippet: A large number of classic characters for children are being freshened up to try to cater to parents’ nostalgia and children’s YouTube-era sensibilities.
articles.abstract: A large number of classic characters for children are being freshened up to try to cater to parents’ nostalgia and children’s YouTube-era sensibilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Strawberry Shortcake was having an identity crisis. The “it” doll and cartoon star of the 1980s was just not connecting with modern girls. Too candy-obsessed. Too ditzy. Too fond of wearing bloomers.

articles.headline: Concerns on Economy Are Shifting to Inflation
articles.snippet: There is a growing sense among investors that the Fed has shifted its focus to the fight against inflation, leaving behind — for now — concerns about the outlook for economic growth.
articles.abstract: There is a growing sense among investors that the Fed has shifted its focus to the fight against inflation, leaving behind — for now — concerns about the outlook for economic growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the past 48 hours, Wall Street has issued a sobering message: The days of easy money from the Federal Reserve are nearly over.

articles.headline: 2 New-Style Candidates Hit Old Notes on Economy
articles.snippet: The economy has Senators John McCain and Barack Obama echoing their party lines.
articles.abstract: The economy has Senators John McCain and Barack Obama echoing their party lines.
articles.lead_paragraph: For all the efforts of Senators John McCain and Barack Obama to portray themselves as willing to break with party orthodoxy to get things done, the economic debate that opened their general election campaign this week previews a classic clash. It is a battle between Republican supply-side economics and a Democratic tradition that uses government levers to try to reduce inequality and spur the economy.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Larry Rohter
